results.adx_keywords: Trading Cards;Nonfungible Tokens (NFTs);Presidential Election of 2024;United States Politics and Government;E-Commerce;Trump, Donald J
results.byline: By Michael C. Bender and Maggie Haberman
results.title: Trump Sells a New Image as the Hero of $99 Trading Cards
results.abstract: Money from sales of the digital trading cards, which depict the former president as characters like a superhero and a “Top Gun”-style fighter pilot, will go directly to him instead of his 2024 campaign.

media.caption: A photo illustration showing former President Donald J. Trump’s newly released digital trading card collection. Incentives to buy the $99 cards include entry into a series of sweepstakes to meet Mr. Trump or golf at one of his properties.

results.adx_keywords: Hotels and Travel Lodgings;Aquariums;Accidents and Safety;Radisson Hospitality Inc;Berlin (Germany)
results.title: Berlin Hotel’s Huge Aquarium Bursts, With 1,500 Fish Inside
results.abstract: A 50-foot-high, 264,000-gallon cylindrical tank called AquaDom, housed in a Radisson in the German capital, spectacularly collapsed, sending waves of water through the building and onto the street.

media.caption: Debris outside the Radisson Hotel in central Berlin on Friday. The hotel was evacuated and the authorities were checking for structural damage.

results.byline: By Mike Isaac and Kate Conger
results.title: Twitter Suspends Accounts of Half a Dozen Journalists
results.abstract: The social media service, which is owned by Elon Musk, said that it suspends accounts that “violate the Twitter rules” but did not provide details.

media.caption: The Twitter profiles of three journalists whose accounts were suspended on Thursday.

results.title: How a Sprawling Hospital Chain Ignited Its Own Staffing Crisis

results.adx_keywords: Emergency Medical Treatment;Doctors;Hospitals;Research;Deaths (Fatalities);Medicine and Health;Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality;American College of Emergency Physicians;Johns Hopkins University
results.title: E.R. Doctors Misdiagnose Patients With Unusual Symptoms
results.abstract: Doctors fail to recognize serious conditions like stroke and sepsis in tens of thousands of patients each year, according to a new study.
org_facet: Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality

media.caption: While these errors remain relatively rare in the emergency room, they are most likely to occur when someone presents with symptoms that are not classic signs of a condition.
media.copyright: Adria Malcolm for The New York Times

results.title: Jimmy Kimmel: Trump NFTs Are ‘Literally Cards Against Humanity’
results.abstract: “At least last time, you got a red hat. Now he’s selling you nothing,” Kimmel said of Trump’s new digital trading cards.

media.caption: “And by the way, we already have Donald Trump trading cards — they’re called subpoenas,” Jimmy Kimmel joked.

results.title: My Stint as the Adulterous Flavor-of-the-Month
results.abstract: I was trying to have an experience and ended up having a life.

results.title: 5 Louisiana Officers Charged in 2019 Death of Black Driver
results.abstract: The charges in the death of Ronald Greene are the first to emerge in a case that has mobilized activists and drawn widespread scrutiny of the Louisiana State Police.

results.title: Couple in Car Survive 300-Foot Fall Into a California Canyon
results.abstract: Rescuers found Cloe Fields and Christian Zelada in the Angeles National Forest after Ms. Fields’s iPhone sent a message via satellite to an emergency call center, the authorities said.

media.caption: Rescuers arrived in a helicopter after a car fell into Monkey Canyon in Angeles National Forest on Tuesday.

results.title: Father of Accused Highland Park Gunman Charged in Connection With Shooting
results.abstract: Robert Crimo Jr., whose son is accused of killing seven people at this year’s Fourth of July parade in Highland Park, Ill., was charged with seven counts of reckless conduct.

results.title: Thousands of Documents Relating to John F. Kennedy’s Assassination Are Released
results.abstract: Researchers said they were just beginning to comb through the 13,173 documents, hoping they might shed further light on the government’s actions before and after Nov. 22, 1963.

media.caption: Lee Harvey Oswald after his arrest on Nov. 22, 1963.
